> Drawing it out, it looks like it should work. 
> However, I suspect that there 
> are structures you can't create that way.  For
> example, A-B-Z and A-C-Z 
> where C and B are siblings.  The only way you could
> construct such a network 
> with this approach is to support removing nodes
> and/or connections.

I'm pretty sure that the A-B-Z and A-C-Z could evolve
just fine.  They just have to come from both mutation
and crossover not strictly mutation of one individual.

I have been working on an implementation of NEAT in
python.  It tracks uniqueness of structural
innovations from start to finish.  

When a new node is added via mutation it is assigned
an id based on the connection it split.  If that
connection has been split previously the new node gets
the same id as the last time it was split.  If the
connection hasn't been split before the next
sequentially available node id is used.

When a new connection is added it checks to see if a
connection between the chosen endpoints has been made
before, the same innovation number is used, if no prio
connection between the endpoints has been made, the
next sequentially available innovation number is used.

The implementation checkpoints the entire state of the
evolutionary process every N generations and can be
restarted from any checkpoint.

I'm not sure how my handling of new structure relates
to the ongoing discussion exactly but it may be of use
to someone.

This isn't a finished product but it works reasonably
well.   

The code can be found here:

http://www.wooleyrhino.com/pyn.html
